choices.text: Lesion of Raphe nuclei in lower pons

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman with excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden muscle weakness is diagnosed with narcolepsy. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Narcolepsy is caused by loss of hypothalamic neurons that secrete orexin (hypocretin), which normally promote wakefulness and prevent REM intrusions.

  • Narcolepsy is a disorder of REM sleep regulation and is marked by:
    • Excessive daytime sleepiness
    • Cataplexy (sudden muscle weakness without loss of consciousness)
    • Disrupted sleep-wake transitions
  • Orexin-producing neurons in the lateral hypothalamus stimulate arousal systems, including the locus coeruleus and reticular activating system
  • Loss of these neurons destabilises the wake REM switch, resulting in sudden REM intrusions and cataplexy

Explanation of other options:

Lesion of anterior hypothalamus (Option B): Causes intense wakefulness, not sleep attacks or cataplexy.

Lesion of Raphe nuclei in lower pons (Option C): Lesions of the raphe nuclei reduce serotonin, primarily disrupting NREM sleep initiation, not causing the REM sleep intrusions characteristic of narcolepsy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old undergoing EEG for suspected seizures shows low-voltage 14 Hz waves in parietal regions. When are these waves most likely recorded?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Low-voltage, 14 Hz waves recorded from parietal regions correspond to beta rhythms, typical of focused, waking alertness. Beta waves (14 Hz in this case) are low-amplitude and are captured most clearly over parietal and frontal regions during focused mental activity.

  • EEG signals are categorised into frequency bands:
    • Delta (<4 Hz): Deep sleep or brain dysfunction (Option D)
    • Theta (4-7 Hz): Drowsiness or emotional stress (Option B)
    • Alpha (8-12 Hz): Relaxed wakefulness (Option A)
    • Beta (13-30 Hz): Active, alert mental state (Option C)

questions.text: A 5-year-old with recurrent seizures has a genetic mutation linked to epilepsy. Which gene mutation could be responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Childhood-onset epilepsy is frequently associated with genetic mutations affecting ion channels and neurotransmitter receptors, collectively called channelopathies. These mutations alter neuronal excitability, leading to epileptogenesis.

Among the listed genes:

  • SCN1A (Option A):
    • Encodes the alpha subunit of the voltage-gated sodium channel
    • The most common mutation seen in childhood epilepsy, especially Dravet syndrome
    • Disrupts sodium influx → increases excitability → severe, refractory seizures
  • SCN1B (Option B):
    • Encodes the beta subunit of voltage-gated sodium channels
    • Modulates the gating and kinetics of the alpha subunit
    • Mutations can amplify excitatory signalling and increase seizure risk
  • GABRB3 (Option C):
    • Encodes the beta-3 subunit of the GABA-A receptor
    • GABA-A is the principal inhibitory receptor in the CNS
    • Mutations lead to reduced inhibitory tone, tipping the balance toward hyperexcitability

Thus, all the listed mutations are implicated in different forms of childhood epilepsy.

Related Important Points:

  • SCN1A mutation is a well-established cause of Dravet syndrome
  • GABA-A receptor mutations are linked to generalised epilepsy syndromes
  • Many idiopathic epilepsies have a polygenic basis, often involving multiple interacting mutations
  • Ion channel dysfunction (channelopathy) is a core mechanism in genetic epilepsies

Key Takeaway:

SCN1A is the most common gene mutation in childhood genetic epilepsy (e.g., Dravet syndrome), but SCN1B and GABRB3 are also implicated.

questions.text: A 30-year-old has worked on the night shift for a long time. He had insomnia. He visited the doctor for the same. The doctor found that his circadian rhythm is altered. Which of the following treatments is useful?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Altered circadian rhythm in shift workers can be corrected using a combination of light therapy, melatonin-based agents, and CNS stimulants to restore sleep-wake synchrony.

  • Circadian rhythm is an intrinsic biological cycle (~24 hours) regulated by the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) and synchronised by environmental cues (especially light).
  • Shift workers often experience circadian misalignment, leading to:
    • Difficulty falling asleep
    • Daytime sleepiness
    • Insomnia
  • Therapeutic interventions:
    • Light therapy: (Option A)
      • Exposure to bright light in the early part of the wake cycle helps re-entrain the biological clock.
      • Particularly useful for shift work sleep disorder.
    • Ramelteon (Melatonin receptor agonist): (Option B)
      • Targets MT1 and MT2 receptors in the SCN
      • Helps initiate and maintain sleep by mimicking melatonin
    • Modafinil (Wake-promoting agents): (Option C)
      • Enhances alertness by acting on dopamine and norepinephrine pathways.
      • Used to combat excessive daytime sleepiness in shift work disorder and narcolepsy.

Key Takeaway:

  • Circadian rhythm disorders especially in shift workers, respond well to a multimodal treatment approach:
    • Light exposure (phase-resetting)
    • Melatonin agonists (sleep induction)
    • Wake-promoting agents (alertness during work hours)

questions.text: A 41-year-old with sleep disturbances shows increased stage 1 and decreased stage 3-4 NREM sleep on EEG. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

EEG changes showing increased stage 1 and decreased stage 3-4 NREM sleep are characteristic of periodic limb movement disorder, a condition associated with repetitive, involuntary movements during sleep.

  • Periodic limb movement disorder (PLMD):
    • Characterised by involuntary, repetitive movements during sleep
    • Commonly involves extension of the big toe, dorsiflexion of the foot and knee
    • Leads to frequent arousals, disrupting deep sleep (stages 3 and 4 of NREM)
    • EEG shows:
      • Prolonged stage 1 NREM (light sleep)
      • Reduced stage 3-4 NREM (deep restorative sleep)
    • Obstructive sleep apnea may present similarly, but is associated with respiratory events
    • Other disorders:
      • Cataplexy: Sudden loss of muscle tone, typically seen in narcolepsy; not associated with this EEG pattern (Option B)
      • Somnambulism (sleepwalking): Occurs during deep NREM (stage 3-4), but does not reduce its duration (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

EEG with increased stage 1 NREM and decreased stage 3-4 NREM is suggestive of periodic limb movement disorder, often due to fragmented sleep caused by rhythmic leg activity.

choices.text: Increased activity of Acetylcholine in pontine neurons
Decreased activity of serotonin in raphe nuclei
Increased activity of norepinephrine in locus coeruleus
Increased GABAergic input to the thalamus

questions.text: A 35-year-old with sleep-wake cycle issues undergoes brain imaging. Which mechanism supports wakefulness?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wakefulness is promoted by ascending arousal systems, particularly via increased norepinephrine release from the locus coeruleus.

  • Wakefulness is maintained by coordinated activity in the ascending reticular activating system (ARAS).
  • Key neurotransmitter systems involved in promoting alertness and arousal include:
    • Norepinephrine from the locus coeruleus
    • Serotonin from the raphe nuclei
    • Histamine from the tuberomammillary nucleus (TMN)
  • These systems activate cortical and thalamic neurons to sustain alert consciousness.
  • Acetylcholine from pontine and basal forebrain neurons becomes more active during REM sleep, not during wakefulness.

Explanation of other options:

Increased activity of acetylcholine in pontine neurons (Option A): Pontine cholinergic neurons are primarily active during REM sleep, whereas basal forebrain cholinergic neurons contribute to wakefulness.

Decreased activity of serotonin in raphe nuclei (Option B):  Serotonin promotes wakefulness; decreased activity contributes to sleep initiation, not alertness.

Increased GABAergic input to the thalamus (Option D): GABA promotes non-REM sleep by inhibiting cortical arousal, the opposite of the wakefulness-promoting effect.

Key Takeaway:

Wakefulness is primarily maintained by monoaminergic neurotransmitters, especially norepinephrine, serotonin, and histamine, originating in the brainstem and hypothalamic nuclei.

choices.text: The surface positive wave followed by a small negative wave is the primary evoked potential
A large positive deflection after latency of 20-80 milliseconds forms a secondary response
Secondary response is highly specific, while the primary response is diffuse.

questions.text: A 37-year-old undergoing evoked potential testing for neurological evaluation shows specific early responses. Which statement about evoked cortical potentials is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Primary evoked potentials are highly specific to the sensory modality, while secondary responses are diffuse and influenced by attentional mechanisms.

  • Evoked cortical potentials are electrical responses generated in the cerebral cortex in response to sensory stimulation.
  • Primary Cortical Evoked Response (PCER):
    • Latency: 5-12 ms
    • Features: Surface positive wave followed by negative deflection (Option A)
    • Source: Primary sensory cortex
    • Nature: Highly specific to the type of sensory stimulus
  • Secondary Cortical Evoked Response (SCER):
    • Latency: 20-80 ms
    • Features: Large diffuse positive wave (Option B)
    • Nature: Less specific, influenced by cognitive factors such as attention
    • Source: Involves wider cortical and thalamic projections, including intralaminar nuclei
    • Evoked potentials are used in neurophysiology to assess sensory pathway integrity.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with frequent brief episodes of sudden behavioural arrest and unresponsiveness. EEG recording shows 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges lasting for approximately 10 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges on EEG with sudden, brief lapses in consciousness confirms petit mal (absence) seizures.

  • Absence seizures are non-convulsive generalised seizures characterised by sudden cessation of activity and blank staring.
  • EEG typically shows 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges lasting around 10 seconds.
  • They are more common in children aged 4-14 years.
  • There is no aura, no postictal confusion, and the episodes often go unnoticed by the child.
  • Absence seizures are differentiated from tonic-clonic seizures by their brief duration, non-motor features, and characteristic EEG pattern.

Explanation of other options:

Simple partial seizures (Option A): involve localised cortical discharge without altered consciousness. EEG does not show spike-and-wave discharges.

Complex partial seizures (Option B): are focal seizures with impaired awareness, commonly originating from the temporal lobe and preceded by aura. EEG features are focal, not generalised.

Grand mal (tonic-clonic) seizures (Option D): involve a tonic phase followed by clonic jerks and are associated with polyspike EEG patterns, not 3/s spike-and-wave complexes.

Key Takeaway:

Absence (petit mal) seizures are brief, non-motor generalised seizures with classic 3 Hz spike-and-wave EEG findings, seen predominantly in children.

choices.text: Reduction of low-threshold T-type Ca++ currents

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy with absence seizures is prescribed ethosuximide. What is its mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ethosuximide inhibits T-type Ca+ channels in thalamocortical neurons, disrupting the oscillatory activity responsible for 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges in absence seizures.

  • Absence seizures involve thalamocortical circuits regulated by T-type Ca2+ channels.
  • Ethosuximide selectively inhibits these channels, reducing neuronal excitability.
  • It is the drug of choice for absence seizures.
  • Other antiepileptic drugs act through GABA modulation or sodium channel blockade, but these are not specific for absence seizures.

Explanation of other options:

Increased GABA release (Option A): This is the mechanism of action of benzodiazepines and barbiturates; ethosuximide does not enhance GABAergic transmission.

Block voltage-gated Na+ channels (Option B): Seen with phenytoin, carbamazepine, valproate; these drugs act on tonic-clonic seizures, not primarily used in absence seizures.

Decreased glutamate release (Option C): Mechanism of gabapentin; not related to ethosuximide's action or primary therapy for absence seizures.

Key Takeaway:

Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for absence seizures. It works by inhibiting low-threshold T-type Ca+channels in thalamic neurons, preventing the characteristic 3 Hz spike-wave discharges.

questions.text: A 24-year-old with fatigue undergoes an EEG, showing a slowed alpha rhythm frequency. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin B12 deficiency slows alpha rhythm frequency due to impaired neuronal metabolism and myelin integrity, affecting cortical excitability.

  • Alpha rhythm is the most prominent resting EEG waveform, recorded mainly over occipital and parietal areas.
  • Normal alpha wave frequency: 8-13 Hz, amplitude: 50-100 μV.
  • Alpha rhythm appears in a relaxed, awake person with eyes closed.
  • Frequency of alpha rhythm decreases in:
    • Vitamin B12 deficiency
    • Hyponatremia
    • Hypoglycemia
    • Decreased body temperature
    • Decreased adrenal glucocorticoids
    • Acute intoxication with alcohol, phenytoin, and antipsychotics

Explanation of other options:

Increased body temperature (Option A): Increases overall EEG frequency, including alpha rhythm.

Decreased arterial pressure (Option B): May alter cerebral perfusion but does not typically reduce alpha frequency directly.

Hyperglycemia (Option D): Has no direct association with the slowing of alpha wave frequency.

Key Takeaway:

Alpha waves slow down in metabolic disturbances like Vitamin B12 deficiency, hyponatremia, and sedative intoxication.

choices.text: In young adults typically sleep starts with Non- REM sleep.
REM sleep duration is more in infants than adults.
REM sleep duration is increased towards the morning.

questions.text: A sleep study is conducted on a healthy adult and an infant. Which statement about sleep stages is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation: /p>

Sleep is broadly divided into NREM (non-rapid eye movement) and REM (rapid eye movement) phases, which alternate in cycles of ~90 minutes. All listed statements are true and supported by physiology:

  • In young adults, sleep starts with non-REM sleep: (Option A)
    • Sleep always begins with NREM (Stage 1 progressing to Stage 4) before the first REM episode, typically 70-90 minutes after sleep onset.
  • REM sleep duration is longer in infants than in adults: (Option B)
    • Neonates spend up to 50% of their sleep in REM (and even more in preterms), while adults have ~20% REM sleep, and this proportion decreases with age.
  • REM sleep duration increases toward morning: (Option C)
    • In each subsequent sleep cycle, REM duration lengthens and becomes more frequent toward the morning, making REM-rich periods dominant late in the sleep cycle.

Related Important Points:

  • NREM sleep has 4 stages: Stage 1 (lightest) to Stage 4 (deepest slow-wave sleep).
  • REM is associated with dreaming, irregular breathing, muscle atonia, and rapid eye movements.
  • Total REM duration and frequency increase across the night.
  • Infants and children show longer total sleep time and more REM sleep than adults.

questions.text: A 48-year-old obese man with loud snoring and daytime sleepiness has obstructive sleep apnea on polysomnography. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CPAP remains the most effective intervention in obstructive sleep apnea by providing positive pressure that keeps the upper airway open during sleep.

  • OSA results from pharyngeal collapse due to reduced upper airway muscle tone during sleep.
  • Clinical features include loud snoring, gasping, nocturnal awakenings, and excessive daytime fatigue.
  • CPAP mechanically splints the airway and restores nocturnal oxygenation and sleep continuity.
  • CPAP improves sleep architecture, cardiovascular health, and quality of life.

Explanation of other options:

Oral mandibular splints (Option A) are effective for mild-to-moderate OSA but are less effective than CPAP for moderate-to-severe cases.

Nasal decongestants (Option B): may relieve nasal obstruction but do not address pharyngeal collapse.

Acetazolamide (Option D): may be used in central sleep apnea, not obstructive sleep apnea, as the primary issue is mechanical obstruction, not ventilatory drive.

Key Takeaway:

CPAP therapy is the first-line treatment for moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea and significantly improves sleep quality by preventing upper airway collapse.

questions.text: A 29-year-old with sleep issues shows 7-15 Hz spindles and biphasic waves on polysomnography without rapid eye movements. Which sleep stage is recorded?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Stage 2 NREM sleep is defined by the presence of sleep spindles (7-15 Hz) and K-complexes, which are high-voltage biphasic waves.
  • These features help stabilise sleep and are involved in memory consolidation.
  • Stage 2 typically follows stage 1 in the NREM cycle and occupies the largest percentage of total sleep in adults.
  • K-complexes are thought to suppress cortical arousal in response to stimuli and are useful in memory consolidation.
  • In stages 3-4 of NREM sleep delta rhythm is obtained due to reduced arousal. In stage 1 NREM sleep, theta rhythm may be obtained. Theta and delta rhythms also appear during wakefulness, which is a sign of brain dysfunction.

Explanation of other options:

REM sleep (Option A): Shows irregular low-voltage, high-frequency EEG (beta-like activity) but lacks sleep spindles and K-complexes.

Awake but eyes closed (Option B): Exhibits alpha wave activity (8-13 Hz) from the occipital cortex, not spindles or K-complexes.

Stage 4 NREM sleep (Option D): Characterised by high-amplitude delta waves (<4 Hz), not by spindles or K-complexes.

Key Takeaway:

Stage 2 of non-REM sleep is marked by the appearance of sinusoidal waves called sleep spindles (7-15 Hz) and occasional high-voltage biphasic waves called K complexes.

questions.text: A 6-year-old learning to spell “ELEPHANT” recalls it better when cued with “ELE.” What type of memory recall is this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Priming is a form of implicit (non-declarative) memory where prior exposure to a partial or related stimulus facilitates faster and more accurate recall of the full stimulus.

  • In this case, exposure to “ELE” improves recall of “ELEPHANT” without conscious effort, reflecting a perceptual priming effect.
  • It is mediated by the neocortex, especially in word-based and perceptual recognition tasks.
  • Other types of implicit memory include:

    • Procedural memory (e.g., motor skills and habits; mediated by the striatum, cerebellum, and motor cortex)
    • Associative learning, such as classical conditioning (involving the amygdala and cerebellum)
    • Non-associative learning, such as habituation and sensitisation (mediated by reflex pathways)
  • In contrast, explicit (declarative) memory involves conscious recall of facts (semantic memory) and events (episodic memory) and is primarily mediated by the hippocampus and medial temporal lobe.

Related Important Points:

  • Implicit memory operates without awareness and includes motor skills, learned associations, and reflexive learning.
  • Priming is crucial in language, perception, and learning, especially in early development.
  • It differs from procedural memory, which requires motor repetition, and from conditioning, which requires a paired stimulus.

Explanation of other options:

Procedural memory (Option A): Involves motor habits like walking or cycling, not partial word-based recall.

Conditioning (Option B): Refers to learned associations (e.g., bell causing salivation)-not applicable here.

Sensitisation (Option C): A non-associative increase in response to a stimulus, unrelated to memory-based word recognition.

Key Takeaway:

Priming is an unconscious memory process that enhances recall through prior exposure, forming a key part of implicit memory mediated by the neocortex.

questions.text: A 23-year-old with bilateral hippocampal resection for seizures cannot form new memories. What type of amnesia is this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anterograde amnesia is the inability to form new long-term memories following hippocampal damage.

  • The hippocampus is critical for converting short-term memory into long-term memory.
  • Damage to the hippocampal or medial temporal lobe structures leads to an inability to store new information.
  • Pre-existing memories remain unaffected since they are stored in neocortical areas.
  • Seen in conditions like bilateral hippocampal resection, hypoxia, and herpes simplex encephalitis.
  • The Papez circuit and related limbic structures also contribute to episodic memory consolidation.

Explanation of other options:

Retrograde amnesia (Option A): involves forgetting previously acquired memories, not failure to form new ones.

Transient global amnesia (Option C): presents with temporary loss of both retrograde and anterograde memory but resolves within 24 hours.

Confabulation (Option D): involves fabrication of false memories, often due to damage in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (e.g., Korsakoff syndrome).

Key Takeaway:

Damage to the hippocampus leads to anterograde amnesia, characterised by an inability to form new long-term memories.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with difficulty in reading, spelling, and word decoding despite normal intelligence and adequate schooling. Clinical evaluation suggests a specific learning disability. Which hypothesis best explains this type of dyslexia as a problem with speech sound representation and retrieval?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The phonological hypothesis attributes dyslexia to a core deficit in the representation and manipulation of speech sounds.

  • Dyslexia is a common developmental disorder involving reading and language-based processing.
  • The phonological theory is the most widely accepted explanation.
  • It postulates impaired phonemic awareness, difficulty in processing the sounds of spoken language.
  • This leads to poor grapheme-phoneme mapping and affects spelling and decoding.
  • Despite normal vision and intelligence, these children struggle with fluent reading.
  • The phonological hypothesis is supported by neuroimaging studies showing reduced activation in the left temporoparietal cortex, critical for phoneme processing and reading.

Explanation of other options:

Rapid auditory processing hypothesis (Option B): suggests the deficit lies in perceiving brief or rapidly changing sounds, not necessarily phonological representation.

Visual theory (Option C): attributes dyslexia to defects in the magnocellular visual pathway, affecting visual processing rather than phoneme recognition.

Processing speed hypothesis (Option D): is a broader cognitive theory, but it does not directly address the phonemic deficits involved in dyslexia.

Key Takeaway:

The phonological hypothesis explains dyslexia as a failure to represent and manipulate speech sounds, leading to impaired decoding and spelling.

questions.text: A 49-year-old right-handed man had an episode of stroke. On investigation, neurologists found that patients have difficulty in recognising familiar faces. Which part of the brain is probably affected in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A lesion in the inferior temporal lobe results in prosopagnosia due to loss of facial recognition ability.

  • The inferior temporal cortex is responsible for high-level visual processing, including facial recognition.
  • Damage to this region disrupts the stored representation of familiar faces.
  • Prosopagnosia is particularly associated with lesions in the right fusiform gyrus, a region within the inferior temporal cortex specialised for facial recognition.
  • It is a selective visual agnosia specific to faces, not associated with memory loss or blindness.
  • Often observed in right hemisphere lesions in right-handed individuals.

Explanation of other options:

Medial temporal lobe (Option A): including the hippocampus, is involved in memory consolidation, not in facial recognition.

Sensory tract (Option B): damage leads to tactile agnosia, not prosopagnosia.

Inferior parietal lobule (Option C): lesions cause spatial neglect, not object or face-specific visual agnosia.

Key Takeaway:

The inferior temporal lobe is critical for facial recognition; damage here causes prosopagnosia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man suffers from bilateral hippocampal damage following a viral encephalitis. He is unable to remember recent personal experiences but can still ride a bicycle and solve puzzles. Which of the following types of memory is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Episodic memory refers to the ability to consciously recall autobiographical events, such as personal experiences, and is highly dependent on the hippocampus and surrounding medial temporal lobe structures.

  • This patient's inability to recall recent experiences is characteristic of episodic memory loss, commonly seen in bilateral hippocampal damage.
  • Memory is broadly divided into:
    • Explicit (declarative) memory-involves conscious recall
    • Implicit (non-declarative) memory-unconscious skills and habits
  • Episodic memory is one subtype of explicit memory, while semantic memory (another explicit type) involves factual knowledge (e.g., capital cities, vocabulary) and is less hippocampus-dependent than episodic memory.
  • Implicit memory forms such as procedural skills, priming, and conditioning are preserved in hippocampal injury because they are mediated by other brain regions (basal ganglia, cerebellum, neocortex).

Related Important Points:

  • Hippocampus is essential for the encoding, consolidation, and retrieval of episodic memories.
  • Semantic memory remains relatively intact unless there is broader medial temporal or cortical involvement.
  • Procedural learning, such as riding a bicycle, is mediated by the cerebellum and striatum.
  • Priming and associative learning are mediated by the neocortex and amygdala/cerebellum, respectively

Explanation of other options:

Associative learning (Option B): is a type of implicit memory involving the amygdala and cerebellum, and is not significantly affected by hippocampal damage.

Procedural memory (Option C): such as riding a bicycle, is preserved in hippocampal damage because it depends on the basal ganglia and cerebellum, not the medial temporal lobe.

Priming and perceptual memory (Option D): rely on the neocortex and remain intact even when the hippocampus is injured.

Key Takeaway:

Damage to the hippocampus impairs episodic memory, while procedural and other implicit forms of memory remain unaffected.

questions.text: A 22-year-old psychology student participates in a neurophysiology experiment. A soft tone is played repeatedly at fixed intervals. Over time, the subject stops reacting to the sound. Which type of learning does this represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Habituation is a non-associative learning form in which repeated exposure to a neutral stimulus results in a gradual decrease in response due to decreased neurotransmitter release.

  • Habituation is a basic form of non-associative learning.
  • The response to a harmless or neutral stimulus decreases upon repeated exposure.
  • Habituation involves synaptic depression in reflex circuits, reducing neurotransmitter release without requiring higher cortical processing.
  • Physiologically, it occurs due to decreased Ca ⁺ influx in presynaptic neurons, reducing neurotransmitter release. Reflex pathways, not higher cortical centres, mediate habituation.

Explanation of other options:

Sensitisation (Option A): results in enhanced response to a repeated or noxious stimulus, due to presynaptic facilitation.

Inhibition (Option B): is not a learning form but a suppression of response unrelated to repetition or stimulus properties.

Classical conditioning (Option D): is associative learning where a neutral stimulus becomes linked to a biologically relevant stimulus (e.g., Pavlov's bell and food).

Key Takeaway:

Habituation is a form of non-associative learning characterised by reduced response to repeated neutral stimuli, mediated via decreased synaptic activity in reflex circuits.

choices.text: Activation of metabotropic glutamate receptors leading to cAMP accumulation
Retrograde signalling via nitric oxide from presynaptic terminals
Calcium influx through NMDA receptor channels in the postsynaptic neuron
Inhibition of GABAergic interneurons surrounding the CA3-CA1 synapse

questions.text: A 19-year-old medical student is undergoing functional brain imaging while learning a new language. Enhanced excitatory postsynaptic potentials are noted in hippocampal neurons following high-frequency stimulation of Schaffer collaterals. Which of the following molecular events is most essential for this observed synaptic plasticity?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

Calcium entry through NMDA receptors triggers intracellular cascades essential for long-term potentiation in the hippocampus.

  • Long-term potentiation (LTP) is the physiological basis of memory encoding and synaptic plasticity.
  • In the hippocampus, particularly at Schaffer collateral-CA1 synapses, glutamate released from presynaptic terminals binds to both AMPA and NMDA receptors.
  • AMPA activation depolarises the postsynaptic membrane.
  • This depolarisation removes the Mg⁺ block from NMDA receptors, allowing Ca⁺ influx.
  • Calcium influx through NMDA receptors activates CaMKII, a key kinase that phosphorylates AMPA receptors, enhancing synaptic strength in LTP.

Explanation of other options:

Activation of metabotropic glutamate receptors leading to cAMP accumulation (Option A): Metabotropic glutamate receptors contribute to plasticity but are not the central mechanism in classical hippocampal LTP.

Retrograde signalling via nitric oxide from presynaptic terminals (Option B): Nitric oxide may act as a retrograde messenger, but is modulatory, not the main mechanism.

Inhibition of GABAergic interneurons surrounding the CA3-CA1 synapse (Option D): Inhibition of GABA interneurons may facilitate LTP, but is not a core requirement.

Key Takeaway:

NMDA receptor-mediated calcium influx is the molecular trigger for long-term potentiation in hippocampal circuits crucial for learning and memory.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male suffered a traumatic brain injury in a road traffic accident. Neurologically, he can recall factual details of past events but is unable to recall the emotional content associated with them. Functional MRI reveals disrupted connectivity between the hippocampus and another deep temporal lobe structure. Which of the following brain structures is most likely damaged, explaining the inability to retrieve emotionally salient memories?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The amygdala’s role in emotional memory is mediated by its connections with the hippocampus for memory consolidation and the prefrontal cortex for emotional regulation.

  • The amygdala, part of the limbic system, is essential for emotional encoding and recall of memories.
  • It plays a key role in assigning emotional salience to neutral stimuli during memory formation.
  • During the retrieval of emotionally charged memories, theta rhythm synchronisation occurs between the amygdala and hippocampus.
  • Bilateral lesions to the amygdala impair emotional memory, although factual (semantic/declarative) memory may remain
  • This disconnection explains the patient's inability to recall emotion-linked content, despite remembering the event itself.

Explanation of other options:

Ventromedial prefrontal cortex (Option A): is involved in emotional regulation and moral behaviour, not primary memory encoding.

Cerebellum (Option B): is involved in procedural memory (motor skills), not emotional or declarative memory.

Neocortex (Option D): supports priming and perceptual memory, primarily non-emotional and implicit.

Key Takeaway:

Amygdala-hippocampal interaction is critical for encoding and retrieving emotionally charged memories.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presents with episodes of sudden intense familiarity while performing routine tasks, such as walking into her living room or listening to someone speak. She insists she has "lived through this moment before,"though she logically knows she hasn't. Neurological evaluation is underway to rule out temporal lobe pathology. Which of the following best describes this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Déjà vu is a false sense of familiarity commonly linked to temporal lobe dysfunction, especially in epilepsy.

  • Déjà vu (French: 'already seen') is the illusion that a current novel experience has been lived through before.
  • It is often seen in focal seizures originating from the medial temporal lobe, particularly as an aura in temporal lobe epilepsy.
  • It represents inappropriate activation of memory circuits, particularly in the hippocampus and associated limbic structures.
  • In healthy individuals, déjà vu may arise from transient mismatches in hippocampal-neocortical interactions, creating a false sense of familiarity.

Explanation of other options:

Confabulation (Option B): is the spontaneous fabrication of false memories, typically seen with ventromedial prefrontal damage or Korsakoff syndrome.

Senile dementia (Option C): (e.g., Alzheimer's disease) involves progressive memory loss and cognitive decline, not brief episodes of false familiarity.

Flashbulb memory (Option D): Refers to highly detailed, vivid recollections of emotionally charged events (e.g., remembering where you were during a disaster); not a pathological misperception like déjà vu.

Key Takeaway:

Déjà vu is a pathologic or benign phenomenon involving false familiarity, linked to temporal lobe activity and memory encoding systems.

choices.text: Impaired conversion of visual input into phonological patterns
Disconnection between comprehension and vocal motor planning centres
Lesion of the auditory association cortex responsible for language comprehension
Defective motor programming of speech production pathways

questions.text: A 21-year-old right-handed male presents with fluent speech following a road traffic accident. His sentences are grammatically structured but lack meaning. He often uses incorrect or made-up words and seems unaware of his language deficit. He is unable to follow both spoken and written commands. MRI reveals a lesion in the dominant hemisphere involving the posterior superior temporal gyrus. Which of the following best explains the nature of this language dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lesion of Wernicke's area, the auditory association cortex, causes fluent but meaningless speech with impaired comprehension.

  • Wernicke's area, located in the posterior superior temporal gyrus, is responsible for language comprehension.
  • Integrates auditory input (via primary auditory cortex) and visual language (via angular gyrus).

Explanation of other options:

Impaired conversion of visual input into phonological patterns (Option A): Refers to an angular gyrus lesion, which causes alexia/anomic aphasia, not global comprehension loss.

Disconnection between comprehension and vocal motor planning centres (Option B): Describes conduction aphasia caused by arcuate fasciculus lesion; comprehension is preserved.

Defective motor programming of speech production pathways (Option D): Characteristic of Broca's aphasia, with non-fluent speech but intact comprehension.

Key Takeaway:

Wernicke's area lesion causes fluent aphasia with impaired comprehension, naming, and repetition, commonly due to temporal lobe damage.

choices.text: Inferior portion of left frontal lobe

questions.text: A 32-year-old accountant complains of increasing difficulty in performing basic arithmetic tasks over the past 10 months. He remains fluent in speech and shows no language or memory deficits. Neurological examination is unremarkable except for inability to perform serial subtractions or simple calculations. MRI reveals a focal cortical lesion. Which of the following brain areas is most likely involved in this patient’s deficit?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acalculia, the inability to perform mathematical calculations, is most commonly linked to lesions of the left parietal lobe, particularly the angular gyrus. This region is responsible for symbolic number processing, numerical comprehension, and calculation.

Lesions in this area can lead to Gerstmann syndrome, which includes:

  • Acalculia
  • Agraphia
  • Finger agnosia
  • Right-left disorientation

In this patient, the isolated arithmetic deficit without language or memory disturbance strongly localizes to the dominant (left) parietal cortex.

Related Important Points:

  • The angular gyrus (Brodmann area 39) integrates visual, auditory, and somatosensory information for language and mathematical processing.
  • Frontal lobe regions (especially dorsolateral prefrontal cortex) are involved in working memory and problem-solving, but basic arithmetic ability is parietally mediated.
  • Hippocampus is associated with episodic memory, not calculation.
  • The right parietal lobe governs visuospatial awareness, not numerical processing.

Explanation of other options:

Right hippocampus (Option A): Involved in spatial and episodic memory, not numerical tasks.

Inferior portion of the left frontal lobe (Option C): Contributes to working memory and executive functions but is not the primary center for arithmetic processing.

Right inferior parietal lobule (Option D): More associated with spatial attention and body schema acalculia localizes to the left hemisphere.

Key Takeaway:

Acalculia is classically caused by a lesion in the dominant (left) parietal lobe, especially near the angular gyrus.
